lesson_title: Compound Words: Two Words Make One New Word
objectives: Understand that compound words are formed by joining two or more smaller words.
Learn to identify common compound words used in daily life and school.
Practice making new compound words by combining simple words.

subtopics.title: 1.1. Joining Two Words for a New Meaning

sections.text: A compound word is a word made by joining two or more smaller, full words together. When these two words come together, they form a new word with a new meaning. Think of it like adding two different fruits to make a new kind of juice!

examples.label: Word 1 + Word 2 = Compound Word
examples.value: Sun + light = Sunlight

examples.label: Word 1 + Word 2 = Compound Word
examples.value: Rain + fall = Rainfall

examples.label: Word 1 + Word 2 = Compound Word
examples.value: Farm + house = Farmhouse

examples.label: Word 1 + Word 2 = Compound Word
examples.value: Back + pack = Backpack

usage_examples: The **sunlight** helps our crops grow.
We get a lot of **rainfall** during monsoon season.
My grandfather lives in an old **farmhouse**.
I carry my books in my **backpack**.
The **moonlight** was bright last night.
We play **football** in the field.

sections.text: These are compound words where the two words are joined together to form a single word without any space or hyphen. They look like one complete word.

examples.label: classroom
examples.value: class + room = classroom (where we study)

examples.label: blackboard
examples.value: black + board = blackboard (where teachers write)

examples.label: bedroom
examples.value: bed + room = bedroom (where we sleep)

examples.label: sunflower
examples.value: sun + flower = sunflower (a tall yellow flower)

examples.label: notebook
examples.value: note + book = notebook (for writing notes)

usage_examples: Our **classroom** is very clean.
The teacher wrote on the **blackboard**.
I sleep in my **bedroom**.
Many **sunflowers** grow near our village.
Write your homework in your **notebook**.
The **farmhouse** is old but strong.
My **schoolbag** is heavy today.
We had **lunchtime** after prayers.

sections.text: Sometimes, the two words are joined by a small line called a hyphen (-). This helps keep the words clear, especially when they are used as one idea.

examples.label: sister-in-law
examples.value: sister + in + law = sister-in-law (your spouse's sister)

examples.label: well-known
examples.value: well + known = well-known (famous or widely recognized)

examples.label: mother-in-law
examples.value: mother + in + law = mother-in-law (your spouse's mother)

examples.label: long-term
examples.value: long + term = long-term (lasting for a long period)

usage_examples: My **sister-in-law** visited us last week.
Our Sarpanch is a **well-known** person in the district.
My **mother-in-law** makes delicious sweets.
We need a **long-term** plan for water storage in the village.
He gave a **heart-warming** speech.

sections.text: In this type, the two words are written separately, but they work together to form a single idea or meaning. You can often tell it's a compound word because the two words commonly appear together.

examples.label: post office
examples.value: post office (place to send letters)

examples.label: full moon
examples.value: full moon (when the moon is fully visible)

examples.label: living room
examples.value: living room (a room in a house for general use)

examples.label: ice cream
examples.value: ice cream (a frozen sweet treat)

examples.label: school bus
examples.value: school bus (a bus for taking children to school)

usage_examples: I went to the **post office** to send a letter.
We saw a **full moon** last night.
My family sits in the **living room** every evening.
Children love to eat **ice cream** in summer.
The **school bus** picks up students from the village.
Always drink **fresh water**.

table.title: Types of Compound Words
rows: Written as separate words, but one idea

topics.title: 3. Common Compound Words in Our Daily Life

subtopics.title: 3.1. Compound Words at Home and School

sections.text: Many things we use and see around our home and school are named with compound words. Learning these helps us speak about our daily surroundings.

examples.label: bedroom
examples.value: The room where you keep your bed and sleep.

examples.label: bathroom
examples.value: The room where you bathe and wash.

examples.label: lunchbox
examples.value: A box used to carry your lunch to school or work.

examples.label: homework
examples.value: Work given by the teacher to be done at home.

examples.label: playground
examples.value: An outdoor area for children to play, often at school.

usage_examples: My **bedroom** has a small window.
Remember to wash your hands in the **bathroom**.
Did you pack your **lunchbox** this morning?
I finished all my **homework** before playing.
We play kabaddi in the school **playground**.
The **blackboard** is cleaned every day.
My **notebook** is full of my writings.
We have school on **weekdays** (Monday to Friday).

subtopics.title: 3.2. Compound Words in Our Village and Nature

sections.text: Our village life and nature also have many things named with compound words. These words help us talk about our surroundings.

examples.label: farmhouse
examples.value: A house on a farm, where the farmer lives.

examples.label: wellwater
examples.value: Water that comes from a well.

examples.label: marketplace
examples.value: An open area where people buy and sell goods.

examples.label: sunlight
examples.value: The light that comes from the sun.

examples.label: rainfall
examples.value: The amount of rain that falls in an area.

usage_examples: Our **farmhouse** is surrounded by green fields.
We use **wellwater** for drinking and cooking.
The **marketplace** is very crowded on Sundays.
We need good **sunlight** for our crops to grow.
Heavy **rainfall** helps fill our village pond.
The **treetops** were swaying in the wind.
The children like to play near the **riverside**.
We saw many **wildflowers** in the forest.
The **postman** delivers letters to our homes.

sections.text: You can try to make your own compound words by joining two words that you already know. Think about how their meanings combine to make a new sense.

examples.label: Word 1: Basket + Word 2: Ball
examples.value: Basket + ball = **Basketball** (a game played with a ball and a basket)

examples.label: Word 1: Gold + Word 2: Fish
examples.value: Gold + fish = **Goldfish** (a small, golden fish often kept as a pet)

examples.label: Word 1: Key + Word 2: Board
examples.value: Key + board = **Keyboard** (used for typing on a computer, or a musical instrument)

examples.label: Word 1: Pan + Word 2: Cake
examples.value: Pan + cake = **Pancake** (a flat, round cake cooked in a pan)

usage_examples: Let's play **basketball** in the evening.
My brother has a **goldfish** in a small bowl.
I typed my homework on the computer **keyboard**.
My mother made fresh **pancakes** for breakfast.
Can you make a compound word with 'sun' and 'set'?
Try to combine 'door' and 'bell' to make a new word.

sections.text: When you make or find a compound word, think about the meaning of each small word, and then how they come together to form the new meaning. This helps you understand the compound word better.

examples.label: Birdhouse
examples.value: Bird (an animal) + house (a home) = a house for birds.

examples.label: Blackbird
examples.value: Black (a color) + bird (an animal) = a specific type of bird that is black.

examples.label: Toothbrush
examples.value: Tooth (part of your mouth) + brush (to clean) = a brush for cleaning teeth.

usage_examples: My father built a **birdhouse** in our garden.
I saw a **blackbird** singing on the tree.
Always use a **toothbrush** to clean your teeth twice a day.
Think about 'rain' and 'coat'. What does 'raincoat' mean?
What is the meaning of 'firefighter'?
